segments.text: Well, the next thing I think he got wrong was he argued too much about the mechanism.
Now, we know very little about the inside of the Earth, and I think one should separate fairly clearly arguments about matters that are fairly direct consequences of observation.
If you're going to argue that continents have split and moved apart, you would best argue it,
on the evidence for it having happened, not on arguments to show that it must happen from models of the Earth.

I mean, it is not a strong argument to say that we know so much about the inside of the Earth that such and such things will happen and the Earth will be split apart, because you know so little about it.
You do better to separate very clearly the evidence for the thing having happened
from the evidence of the reasons why it happens.
You can see this in an ice age.
For a hundred years we've known there have been ice ages and the evidence for this is seen in the mountains.
The evidence for glacial periods in Europe and North America is overwhelming.
But we still don't know why they happen.
You can perfectly well have accepted facts and a view of a historical process without knowing
the driving mechanism.
And if you start arguing too early about the driving mechanism, you'll get into a morass of controversy with theoretical physicists.
Another nice example of this is the example of cigarette smoking and cancer, which was an observed fact before there was a theory of it.
There isn't much of a theory now.
And another one is cholera.

that cholera was discovered to be waterborne before it was known to be due to bacteria and so that I think Wegener made fundamental misjudgments about how to conduct a scientific argument and the literature of the 20s is extremely interesting I've written a paper on this so I won't say any more about it there's a paper in last year's advances in geophysics in which I
I've collected a lot of quotations in the literature of the period.
Things like, there's a man who says, the idea of continental drift is a beautiful vision and we try and clasp it in our arms and embrace it and it dissolves and we are left with nothing.
He was, of course, a Frenchman.
Well, anyway,
Wagner, by and large, lost the argument in North America and in England.
He did not lose it in the southern hemisphere.
In South Africa, the evidence is very much clearer.
The reason being that on the whole, the geological structures in South America and in South Africa run across the coast.
I mean, for example, the
the Fold Mountains of Cape Province.
They run parallel to the south coast, but they run across and out to sea around Cape Town, and are picked up again on the other side in, I think it's Ecuador.
I never know which South American republic is which.
And very, sorry, Dutoit, the South African geologist, Alexander Dutoit, went to South America.
and wrote a beautiful passage in which he said he found it hard to believe he was not in some rarely visited part of the Cape Province.
The complete succession of the rocks, the point at which the ice ages occurred, everything repeated.
And it was much more obvious in South Africa and South America than it was in North America where the structures, the Appalachian Mountains, run parallel to the coast and then up into Greenland.
So that Wegener lost the argument before the war, and the argument died during the 30s for lack of new things to say about it.
And when I came into these things, geological feeling was very strong in favor of the permanence of the oceans and the stability of the continents.
And after the war, there were various converging things which made
caused the revolution of thought.
The first, I think, was the study of paleomagnetism.
Paleomagnetism is the study of fossil compasses.

This showed, at first it looked rather probable, gradually became more and more likely that the continents had moved relative to each other because the compasses buried in the rocks did not all point to a single pole.
And I was personally convinced, I was more or less convinced early on by Keith Runkall of Newcastle.
Runkall and Blackett were the great new originators of this.
Work had been done by the French at the beginning of the century, and no one paid the slightest attention to it.
Largely, I think, because it was written in French.
Very curious that this very good French work of the early 1900s was completely ignored and then extracted later.
All the references to this will be found in my paper.
But Runcorn was also, I think, psychologically unwise.
When he had a moderate case, he insisted that everyone must believe it.
I remember him saying to me once, Teddy, you do agree, don't you?
And I said, well, Keith, it looks like it.
It looks it's all right.
but I don't feel 100% certain, I don't feel it's conclusive.
And he said, Teddy, those who are not with us are against us.
Well, this kind of attitude, you see, stiffened people's objections, really.
I'd have believed it, I think, a year before, if it hadn't been for the way Runcorn approached it.
But then one of Runcorn's students, a man called Irving, who was also at Cambridge in the later part of this exercise, he was in Manchester with Blackhead at first,

Incidentally, Rumcorn got the professorship in Newcastle, and actually I was to a great extent instrumental in getting him the professorship in Newcastle, mostly because I wanted his job in Cambridge.
He's the man who had the bottom of the heap job, which I took in Cambridge.
There are various funny stories connected with this exercise, the effort to get Runcorn, who was then very young, put into a, made head of the physics department in Newcastle.
Well, anyway, Runcorn, very bright, good man indeed, but not the most tactful man in the world.
Well, then, the first thing then that looked really conclusive was the paleomagnetism.
At the same time, the study of the oceans was going on, and the first thing that looked odd
was that the sediments were so thin.
If the oceans had always been there, one would expect kilometers of sediment, but 100 meters was quite rare.
Sediments, really very thin sediments, particularly in the middle of the oceans, sediments thickening as you went out.
Then it was gradually borne in on us that the sediments were all fairly recent.
In the last 10% or so
less than that, the last five or ten percent of geological time.

A very striking observation, but at first of course not so striking because one found the sediments were young and one said, well of course they're young, they've just been put down on the bottom, we're looking at the surface of the superficial layer.
But then we started to get sediments going back a couple of hundred million years.
which is only a small portion of the history of the Earth.
But there were plenty of sediments back a couple of hundred million years, and then nothing.
So there was this very surprising result that we had sediments, not only recent sediments, but sediments up to a certain age, and then nothing.
And of course, this was quite mysterious and was only a thing.
No one discovered it.
It just gradually appeared as we collected data.
The man who made the great jump, I think, was Harry Hess, in a way.

Harry Hess, who was also brought into this subject by Dick Field, was interested in the mid-ocean ridges, and via a process which has never been entirely clear to me, said that he thought that new ocean crust was being formed there.
Various people had said it before.
I had said this.
I was surprised to find the other day
that I had said this just after the war, I think.
But without the idea that there was sea floor spreading, that this involved, I said crust is being formed, and I hadn't realised quite that this involved moving the other out of the way.
But he said the idea of sea floor spreading, that new crust was being formed on the axis, and the old crust was moving away.
And then it was not a great jump to say, well, there are no earthquakes on the junction of
the Atlantic and Europe, or the Atlantic and North America, the Atlantic and South America, the Atlantic and Africa, and therefore nothing's happening there.
The continents are moving with the oceanic crust.
But this was not very clear, not very obvious.
It was an idea of Hesse's.
I didn't take it all that seriously.
It was produced, I think, somewhere about 1960.
And then
This party we had in the Indian Ocean, the penny drop fall, we'd been doing magnetic survey at sea for some years.
And we had found ups and downs in the intensity of the magnetic field, which were clearly connected with, in some way, with the magnetization of the sea floor.
But we didn't understand it.
I made something of an ass to myself by writing a review of the subject without seeing the point.
Very interesting to look back at it now, somewhere about 1960.
I wrote an article, it was published a year or more later, in which I didn't see the point.
And then, Matthews and Vine, who were in a naval ship in the Indian Ocean, doing a detailed survey of a square degree in the Indian Ocean.
I'd always had a desire
to do a detailed survey of a small piece of the mid-ocean ridge.
I made the suggestion before the war, and war came too soon, and eventually in 1962, I think it was, we did this square debris.

I wasn't there, it was done by Matthews and Vine in a naval survey ship, and they were able, as well as doing the topography, to do the magnetic field, and they did a very detailed survey, and they saw
that certain of the mountains on the bottom of the sea were magnetised the wrong way round.

Well, and then the penny dropped and they said all these ups and downs, wiggles of the magnetic field on the bottom of the sea are a record, a tape recording of the reversals of the Earth's magnetic field.
They're recorded on the axis of the ridge as the lavas cool and then they're carried away by, the tape moves away and a double recording is made
I'm not going to explain this in detail.
Myself and everyone else have written numerous papers about it.
But this was the, in practice, the conclusive thing.
But it's interesting, only two years before, I had been asked to give a talk to the Geological Society of London.
I was rung up by the president, Ullman.
And he said, look, we've got a set of Bolsheviks in this society.
who think that the meetings ought to be interesting.
And they say our meetings are too dull and too detailed and we ought to have some review lectures.
And he said, would you give a review lecture?
We feel we can't oppose this.
We must, the council feels that it must give in to some extent.
And would you give a lecture?
I said, please do.
And he said, what will you talk about?
And I said, I will talk about continental drift.
And he said, oh, will you?
And I said, yes, I'd like to.
And he said, well, of course,
there's never many people come to the June meeting.
Perhaps we could have it there.
So I said, all right, that'd be nice.
And so I came along to the June meeting and I went in to tea.
There seemed to me to be a fair number of people in tea.
And the Genealogical Society is an old-fashioned body and it's customary for the fellows to go in, the audience to go in and sit down and wait a moment.
And then the
the president and the secretaries and the treasurer walk in, a sort of concession.
This time they couldn't get in because all the aisles were blocked by people sitting in them.

We had the biggest audience who could possibly get into the room, people poking their heads through the doors, and the president and the secretaries had to come in through the window from the courtyard outside.
Well, this I took as a sign that it was an idea whose time had come,
And I gave a talk not using the ideas that Vine and Matthews were having.
I think they hadn't quite been produced at the time I gave the talk.
And when I wrote it up, I thought it would be unfair to them to steal their thunder.
So the paper, both as given and as published, arrives at what's clearly now the correct conclusion about the motion of the continents and the youth of the sea floor.
from the other arguments of paleomagnetism and various other things.
And I think this had a certain influence, and the interesting thing was that a number of eminent geologists got up and said they'd already always believed it.
But what had stopped them saying so was that Harold Jeffries said that it was impossible.
Well, this again is the point, you see, that humans believe things on their own evidence.
and not because some mathematician tells you they can't work.

And one man, Edward Battisfee Bailey, who was director of the Geological Survey some years ago, a very old friend of mine, got up and said, in fact, he had given a lecture on the subject in, I think it was 1910, in the Old Vic Theatre to some audience.
How he could have come to give a lecture in a theatre on continental drift, I don't know.
But he'd never written it up, and as far as I can make out, he'd never mentioned the question again.
Very curious thing.
And I think Jeffries really had a considerable influence, and also the fanatical opposition of eminent geologists in this country.
The things they said about continental drift and about , you wouldn't believe.
Someone or other, I forgot who it was now, said that he thought there should be a rule in all geological societies that this matter should not be mentioned again.
This was in 1929.
I give all the quotations and references to this in my paper.
Now, current biography in 1954, as long as we're talking about the spirit, states that you had an interest in the utilization of solar energy from eucalyptus trees.
Oh, I know what that is.
I was interested in solar energy, and I

I think I became interested in it during the first Labour government, not the first Labour government, the Labour government just after the war, when I was first director of the National Physical Lab.
They believed that the wicked capitalists had prevented the British public from getting the advantages of science for their own nefarious reasons.
And one of the things that was raised was that nothing was being done about solar energy.
And that this was a wicked plot by the capitalists.
Well, I was asked about this, and I said I didn't believe it.
But they said, well, look, would you set up a committee to inquire into this?
So I set up a committee, Patrick Blackett, myself, Will Hawthorne, Barry Sullivan, about half a dozen of us.
And I was chairman, and I wrote the report, and I think really did most of the work.
I've always regarded the report as one of my publications, but in fact, it is a production of the committee.
And this is really a child's guide to the subject, it doesn't?
It's quite short, and it considers in a rough way all the possibilities.

And in this, one of the possibilities that's considered is that you might have a continually regenerating forest in which you burnt wood and replanted the forest and kept going on a given bit of land.
And we show, this is clearly impractical,
for a pastation of any useful size.
But everyone quotes this for some reason.
Well, this thing was published at the time and the reference is in my bibliography.
So that was my first interest, really, in the matter, that I was chairman of this committee that looked into it.
The report is fairly adverse to the uses of solar energy for the reasons that have become very apparent since
for what you get out of it.
I mean, at the time when oil was cheap, it was clearly just not on, except for specialized requirements.
I mean, if you live in a desert miles from anywhere, it may well pay you to have solar energy to work your pumps in some way.
But in general terms, it just wasn't on.
Naturally, the increase in the price of oil has improved things somewhat, but unfortunately, Capital Plant has gone up by about as much as oil has.
the increase in price of capital plant exceeds the general inflation.
So it's not really very promising today, except for things like heating swimming pools, who just about break even.
The interest on the capital required to warm a swimming pool is just about compensates for the cost of the gas you would burn.
But of course there is the risk that they stop you burning gas and heating swimming pools, so then it might be attractive.
Well, the next thing that happened about that was that I had a phone call
In those days, about 1954, I suppose.
And in those days, there was only radio communication across the Atlantic.
And I couldn't hear what was being said.
The only thing I could hear was that the man on the other end was asking me whether I would deputize for the chairman of General Motors, who was sick.
And I thought to myself, this is the only time I'm ever going to deputize for the chairman of General Motors.
So I said, I can't hear what you say.
But the answer is yes, write and tell me what it is you want me to do.
And it turned out they wanted me to make a keynote address to a conference on solar energy in Tucson, Arizona.
So I went over there, and I was in a bit of a jam, because I was, after all, the chairman of this committee that produced an adverse report.
And this meeting was clearly full of solar energy buffs.
And so I didn't know quite what to do, because I didn't want to be rude to the audience or to
the people who'd asked me.
So I got up and I said what I thought about solar energy, a slightly softened version of what I'd said before.
I mean, partly about the difficulties and the amount of work that needed to be done and so on.
And then I said how good it was to be in America and how much I'd got from my visits to America and how much I appreciated it all, which no one ever does say.
People in Europe think they're invited to America
because it's their right to be invited.
It never occurs to anyone, really, to say thank you.
And this was a tremendous success.
I was asked out that night by Luke Douglas, who was an ambassador in London, or had been shortly before.
He was a one-eyed banker, became a great friend of mine afterwards.
I've met him, he's dead now, I've met him many, many times.
And the mayor of Tucson and the governor of Arizona, I forget who was governor of Arizona there, it was Gold...
Goldberg's, what's his name?
Goldwater?
Goldwater's predecessor.
Well anyway, they took me out for what in England we call a pub call.
We went from one bar to another and they taught me how to mix various drinks.
I remember it was my first introduction to a vodka martini.
And really most entertaining and a very curious
exercise a bit for an ambassador, a governor, and a mayor to go around from one pub to another.
Of course, they were greeted everywhere with enthusiasm.
They all got freshly drunk.
Well, anyway, I tried afterwards to feed the chairman of the Russian Academy of Sciences on vodka martinis, but he wouldn't drink them.
He said, you can't mix up vodka like the Americans do.
You've got to drink it and eat.
Well, anyway, that's the sum total of my connection with solar energy.
Now, is there any personal history of the Bullard Brewing Company your great-grandfather founded?
Why were you directed for five years?
Well, it was founded, as you say, by my great-grandfather, Richard Bullard, and that was taken on by my grandfather, who was quite a character.
a member of parliament for Norwich until he was ejected for bribery.
Bribery in those days was a relatively minor thing.
You distributed half crowns to people in pubs to vote for you.
I mean, about 20 cents or something of this sort.
And he was caught on this.
When he got back to Norwich after having been expelled, he was met at the station by a large crowd who took the horses out of his carriage and dragged him in triumph through the streets.
He was very popular locally.
And a very considerable character.
Well, I'm not going to tell stories about him.
I never knew him.
He died before I was born.
And then my father took over the brewery and various uncles.
My father was the main man in running the brewery.
And he, my father, thought I was, regarded me as totally impractical.
And for many years was exceedingly worried lest I shouldn't be able to earn my living.
when I was a boy at school that I should become qualified as a chartered accountant, and then go as an accountant into the brewery.
And I remember him giving me some small sum of money, investing it for me.
He produced an income of about 100 a year.
And he said, at any rate, Edward, every day of your life, you'll be able to buy yourself lunch.
Little did he know about inflation.
And this was a very curious thing.
There was really no reason to suppose I couldn't look after my son.
If I had been, as a small child, as I said yesterday, I'd been disturbed when I was 10.
But he never realized I'd grown up, I don't think.
And so I never had any connection with the brewery as long as he was alive, really.
I knew my way around it.
I used to go down with him as a child.
He was very kind to me.
Every Saturday morning I used to go down
and meet him at the brewery and we'd go around and make the measurements of the density of the beer or the hydromaton and look around and see that everything was clean and tidy.
And then, when he died, we found the brewery in quite a mess in the sense that my father believed that money was bad for people.
In particular, it was bad for the shareholders.
And therefore he distributed the minimum possible amount in dividends
And it stepped the money away.
So there was a very large collection of cash.
And the company was a public company.
And you could buy the shares on the stock market.
He'd been forced to make it a public company because he got into trouble with the taxation people who insisted on making it a public company.
And if you'd bought the shares on the stock market and got control, you'd have found enough money to pay for them.
And my cousin and I were very disturbed about this.
My cousin asked me to become a director.
And the rest of the directors were employees of the company.
So in effect, what my cousin and I said went, because we could just have removed the other directors if necessary.
So we ran this thing.
My cousin ran it really, and I used to go pretty frequently.
And we started buying other breweries with this money.
We bought the breweries, and we closed them down, and kept their pubs.
So we had more and more pubs.
And this was going splendidly.
We were all making our fortunes.
Suddenly one day we found that Watkins, one of the big national brewers, were buying our shares.
And we became rather disturbed about this, and eventually they came out into the open and said they wished to buy the thing.
And the price they offered was so high that it was clear that a lot of the shares were held by trustees for old ladies in the older generation of the family.
And the trustees would certainly have sold the shares at the price that was offered, which was ludicrous.
And so we very regretfully accepted, I think, 9.2 million for an enterprise that could have been bought for 1.5 million three or four years before.
So we did extremely well out of it, but I very much regretted it.
It's certainly been not in the public interest and not in our interest.
We could have made more money by going on as we were.
We had other views for gobbling up other breweries.
And we were doing very well.
And what's the public is?
It's given them no choice between their beers.
They have to drink Mr. Watney's beer now.
And it didn't do the Watneys much good.
Of course, Mr. Watney paid so much for the thing that they got into financial difficulties.
And the next takeover they tried to do failed.
And then they got caught themselves by a purely financial group.
And this group paid so much for Watneys that they're now in financial difficulties.
So everyone concerned is in financial difficulties.
except the shareholders of the company of Bullards and the companies we took over.
Of course, the people who were in the shares of some of the breweries we took over have been taken over three times, once by us, once by Watney's, and once by these financiers.
And they've gained factors varying between 2 and 10 every time.
So a very curious story.
But that's how I became to be in the brewing business.
I was a consultant to Watney's afterwards.
It was all done quite amiably.
And now I have a pension from Watney's.
Not very much, but I do get a pension from Watney's.
